metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of hydrometeorological observation network (No.2 runoff observation system of 312 bridge on the Heihe River, 2014)
metadata.description:
The data set includes the observation data of river water level and velocity at No.2 point in the runoff densification observation of the middle reaches of Heihe River from January 1, 2014 to December 31, 2014. The observation point is located in Heihe bridge, 312 National Road, Zhangye City, Gansu Province. The riverbed is sandy gravel with unstable section. The longitude and latitude of the observation points are N38 ° 59 ′ 51.71 ″, E100 ° 24 ′ 38.76 ″, with an altitude of 1485 meters, and a channel width of 70 meters and 20 meters. Sr50 ultrasonic range finder is used for water level observation, with acquisition frequency of 30 minutes. The data description includes the following parts:            For water level observation, the observation frequency is 30 minutes, unit (CM); the data covers the period from January 1, 2014 to December 31, 2014; for flow observation, unit (M3); for flow monitoring according to different water levels, the water level flow curve is obtained, and the runoff change process is obtained based on the observation of water level process. The section of bridge no.2-312 is frequently disturbed by human beings, and the unstable area of hydrological section leads to the disorder of water level and flow curve. During the measurement, the stable flow and water level curve cannot be obtained. The missing data is uniformly represented by string-6999.            
Refer to Li et al. (2013) for hydrometeorological network or station information and he et al. (2016) for observation data processing.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to observe water vapor and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used in this domain is the eddy covariance system and scintillometer for acquiring half-hourly turbulent flux data. Additionally, automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period collect hydrometeorological data such as radiation, soil heat flux, temperature profiles, and soil moisture.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting stable flow rate data in hydrometeorological observations?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge is the unstable water level-flow rate curve at observation points like the 312 bridge section in the Heihe River Basin, where frequent anthropogenic disturbances and unstable cross-section areas hinder the acquisition of stable flow rate data.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that integrates eco-hydrological data with remote sensing techniques in arid regions?
Example.Answer: A multiscale dataset from the Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) integrates eco-hydrological data with remote sensing techniques, using instruments such as LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in an oasis-desert area.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with obtaining stable hydrological measurements in river basins?
Definition.Answer: Obtaining stable hydrological measurements in river basins can be challenging due to factors like frequent human disturbances, which affect the stability of hydrological cross-sections and lead to inconsistent water level-flow curves, as seen in the fluctuating conditions of the Heihe River basin.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for hydrometeorological observations in oasis-desert systems compare to those used for river streamflow measurements in terms of frequency and equipment used?
Comparison.Answer: Hydrometeorological observations in oasis-desert systems utilize instruments like eddy covariance systems and automatic weather stations with average periods of 10 minutes, while river streamflow measurements use equipment such as SR50 ultrasonic distance sensors with a frequency of 30 minutes. The former involves a broader array of parameters including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, whereas the latter focuses on river water level and flow velocity.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in the challenges faced when collecting data in the oasis-desert regions compared to the river streamflow measurement sites?
Comparison.Answer: Both oasis-desert regions and river streamflow measurement sites face challenges related to environmental stability and human disturbance. In oasis-desert regions, challenges include ecological degradation and frequent dust storms, whereas river streamflow sites face issues like unstable hydrological cross-sections due to human disturbances, which result in chaotic water level-flow curves.

Interpretation.Question: How might the frequent disturbances and unstable cross-sectional area at the hydrometeorological observation point affect the reliability and interpretation of water level and flow rate data?
Interpretation.Answer: The frequent disturbances and unstable cross-sectional area at the observation point can lead to a chaotic water level-flow rate curve, making it difficult to obtain stable relationships between these measurements. This could complicate the understanding of runoff changes and hydrological processes in the area.

Interpretation.Question: What are the implications of using advanced remote sensing technologies, such as LiDAR and imaging spectrometers, for data interpretation in eco-hydrological research?
Interpretation.Answer: Advanced remote sensing technologies like LiDAR and imaging spectrometers allow for high-resolution and wide-area data collection, which can significantly enhance the understanding of spatial patterns and processes. These technologies enable detailed mapping and monitoring of environmental variables, contributing to more accurate and holistic interpretations of eco-hydrological dynamics.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the difficulty in obtaining stable flow level curves in the context of hydrological measurements?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: One significant factor is the frequent human disturbance at observation sites, leading to unstable hydrological cross-section areas, which complicates the measurement and results in non-uniform flow level curves.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is multiscale observation challenging in eco-hydrological research, particularly on heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenge arises from the poor availability of multiscale observations, which hinders progress in understanding and modeling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces, as there is a need for comprehensive data across various scales.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes ecological environment degradation in arid and semiarid inland river basins, impacting long-term data collection efforts?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Ecological degradation is caused by factors such as drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms, particularly in areas along the Silk Road, affecting the ability to maintain consistent long-term data collection.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of utilizing multiscale observations on the understanding of eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing multiscale observations can significantly enhance the understanding of eco-hydrological processes by addressing the challenge of poor availability of data. It allows for capturing multi-scale and multidisciplinary data, which is crucial in understanding the complex interactions within oasis-desert systems. This could lead to more effective strategies for maintaining ecological stability and supporting sustainable development in these areas.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of frequent human disturbances on the stability and accuracy of hydrometeorological data collection in river basin systems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Frequent human disturbances, such as those affecting the river basin systems, can lead to instability in hydrological cross-sectional areas, which affects the accuracy and reliability of hydrometeorological data collection. This instability can result in disordered water level-flow curves, making it challenging to obtain stable and accurate runoff measurements, thereby complicating the interpretation and application of the collected data.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it essential to maintain continuous hydrometeorological observations in inland river basins of arid and semiarid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Continuous observations are necessary to monitor and address the ecological environment degradation crises faced by these regions, such as drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, and intensification of land desertification. This is critical for achieving sustainable development and ecological stability.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instrumentation setup and procedures are employed to capture multiscale eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The instrumentation setup involves arranging instruments in hierarchically nested scales, including a flux observation matrix with eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations, as well as eco-hydrological sensor networks measuring soil moisture and leaf area index. Additionally, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer is utilized.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data collected and processed in artificial and natural oasis–desert systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data are collected using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers. Data collection involves hydrometeorological measurements, including radiation, soil heat flux, temperature profiles, and air pressure. Data processing encompasses data collection, processing, and archiving, with quality control procedures applied throughout these stages.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are used to ensure the quality control of observational data collected in eco-hydrological studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Quality control methods include careful sensor calibration, data collection, processing, and dataset generation. These procedures are implemented to maintain the integrity of observational data, and the processed data are made freely available at repositories like figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Enablement.Question: What instrumentation techniques have enabled the collection of multiscale eco-hydrological data in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: Instrumentation techniques such as the use of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer have enabled the collection of multiscale eco-hydrological data in arid regions.

Enablement.Question: In what ways does the use of automatic weather stations enhance the monitoring of hydrometeorological parameters in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Automatic weather stations enhance the monitoring of hydrometeorological parameters in oasis-desert ecosystems by providing continuous observations of variables such as radiation, soil heat flux, air temperature gradients, wind speed, air pressure, and precipitation with a 10-minute average period.

Expectation.Question: Why might frequent human disturbances at a river cross-section lead to challenges in obtaining stable water level-flow curves in hydrological observations?
Expectation.Answer: Frequent human disturbances at a river cross-section can impact the stability of the hydrological cross-section area, leading to disruptions in the water level-flow relationship, which hinders the ability to obtain consistent water level-flow curves.

Expectation.Question: Why might long-term observations be indispensable for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: Long-term observations are crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems because they provide comprehensive temporal data necessary to capture seasonal and interannual variability, which is essential for recognizing interactions and supporting sustainable development and ecological stability in these areas.

Judgmental.Question: What are the challenges associated with obtaining stable water level-flow curves in river systems with unstable cross-sections?
Judgmental.Answer: The 312 bridge cross-section in the Heihe River basin experienced frequent human disturbances, leading to unstable hydrological cross-sections and resulting in chaotic water level-flow curves. This instability prevented the acquisition of stable flow level curves during the measurement period.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways can long-term datasets enhance our understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: Long-term datasets collected from oasis-desert systems, including energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, as well as hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters, are crucial for recognizing oasis-desert interactions. These datasets support the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases by providing insights into the fundamental characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange necessary for sustainable oasis development.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges in maintaining stable hydrological measurements in areas with unstable riverbed conditions.
Assertion.Answer: In areas with unstable riverbed conditions, such as the one described in the metadata, the challenges include frequent human disturbances that lead to an unstable cross-sectional area of the riverbed. This instability causes disruptions in the water level and flow rate data, making it difficult to obtain consistent and reliable flow curves.

Request/Directive.Question: What are the various data collection techniques used in obtaining multiscale and multidisciplinary data for eco-hydrological processes in arid and semi-arid regions, and how do these techniques address the challenges of data availability?
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection techniques for multiscale and multidisciplinary data include intensive observation periods (IOPs), continuous hydrometeorological observations, and instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales. These techniques involve the use of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, eco-hydrological sensor networks, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer, as well as synchronical ground measurements. These methods address the challenges of data availability by capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes and providing a comprehensive dataset that is freely available at repositories such as figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Request/Directive.Question: How do researchers ensure the quality control of datasets collected from eco-hydrological observations in oasis-desert systems, and what are the key components of this quality control process?
Request/Directive.Answer: Researchers ensure the quality control of datasets by following a structured process that includes sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. This process involves the acquisition of half-hourly turbulent flux data using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer, observation of hydrometeorological data from automatic weather stations, and supplementation of vegetation and soil parameters. The quality control procedure is crucial for maintaining the reliability and accuracy of the observational data, thereby supporting the ecological security and sustainable development of oasis-desert ecosystems.

Request/Directive.Question: What are the main challenges faced in collecting and processing data for hydrometeorological and eco-hydrological research in inland river basins of arid and semi-arid areas, and what strategies are employed to overcome these challenges?
Request/Directive.Answer: The main challenges faced in data collection and processing include ecological environment degradation, such as drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These challenges are especially prevalent in inland river basins along the Silk Road. To overcome these challenges, researchers employ strategies such as establishing a network of land surface flux and meteorological stations, conducting long-term observations, and employing robust data processing and quality control procedures. These strategies help provide comprehensive datasets that support the understanding and management of oasis-desert interactions and contribute to sustainable development goals.
